file_content.text: I have a confession to make--my qualifications as a medical doctor have... lapsed.
You know I enjoy your company, but perhaps a bit of distance...?
Cipher! I've finished unpacking the last of my equipment.
Between your ship's onboard systems and my custom apparatus, you'll soon have the finest in-flight laboratory in the sector.
You'll make us the envy of the fleet.
Glad to hear it.
Then I'll refrain from publicizing it.
This in-flight laboratory of mine--does it serve a particular purpose?
What's your equipment for?
For now, I expect to find it occupied by the rakghoul data we procured. But I'm sure we'll find other uses.
Officially, of course, I'm in semi-retirement monitoring background radiation somewhere in the Zetan Wastes. Unofficially, I'm very much looking forward to traveling with you.
Understood, doctor. I've never been to the Zetan Wastes, and we have never met.
Then we'll keep this private.
An excellent start. I expect this should prove very interesting.
What exactly is your position in Imperial Intelligence?
You're supposed to be retired?
Let's just say the current administration is happy that I'm off Dromund Kaas--but they're willing to turn a blind eye.
I plan to run your status past Keeper as soon as possible.
We do things by the book here.
I wouldn't bother. If I were to officially transfer to your team, it would cause political complications. Your superiors will turn a blind eye.
I allowed you to come on-board, but I have little tolerance for your babbling.
Spare me, doctor.
I see I'll have to leave you your space.
Should you need anything from me, you only have to ask--although if you want my genetic code rewritten, let me know before we leave the ship.
Make sure I'm in the loop on your work. Otherwise, no immediate requests.
Keep me informed.
I thought you could become a rakghoul whenever you wanted.
You can't transform at will?
It's somewhat more complicated and time-consuming. Nothing to be concerned with, but rarely an option in the field. Good day.
Keep your claws off the other passengers--and try not to scuff the floors.
Just don't eat the crew.
Of course. This is going to be invigorating for both of us.
Doctor. What can I do for you today?
I was just thinking what a fine team we've made. You realize that when we met I had an extremely low opinion of you?
I assumed you'd earned your position through political connections. I made that mistake with an agent once before.
What agent would that be?
Go on.
A man who was promoted to Keeper, and eventually Minister. Clever, if confounding. He'll have my eternal respect.
I don't suppose I've earned your approval yet.
Has your opinion changed?
In part, I'll grant.
As I recall, you were full of compliments when we met.
You claimed you liked me.
Guilty as charged.
The agent I'm thinking of--he was promoted to Keeper, and eventually Minister. A very clever man, who will have my eternal respect.
Your path may be similar to his. Given that, and the state of our Empire, I believe it's wise if I continue to advise you.
I believe it's wise to keep you at my side.
I'm glad to have you here.
Then you're learning.
You think the state of the Empire is so poor?
You sound a little grim.
I think we've both seen things in recent years.
I'm nothing like the old Minister, and I'm very good at surviving.
Don't compare me to him.
Of course, agent.
In any case, I'm at your disposal. And one of these days, you should consider training more operatives. I'll be happy to grant my insight.
We have returned from Project Protean. The task is done.
And I have promises to keep.
It seems Protean was based on prior experiments in alien biology. My prior experiments.
I had no proof until I discovered certain former associates in the Protean lab. But I've ensured that they will not misuse my research again.
What did you do at the research facility?
What happened there?
How exactly were you involved in Project Protean's origins?
Tell me about your past.
Some years ago, I worked on Project Harvest. I had an... attack of conscience, resigned, and took my research with me. Or so I thought.
Your associates said you left because you wanted more control.
They would, wouldn't they? Now they've been dealt with.
You must've recognized your research from the beginning. You knew who was after you.
You knew all along!
I suspected, but I couldn't be sure.
There is more.
Vector and I entered the facility as planned, and "interviewed" the woman in charge.
In return for my generosity sparing the laboratory, I've been appointed unofficial Protean director. From now on, every experiment, every assay goes through me.
That's quite a victory. What do you plan to do with that authority?
Impressive work, Doctor.
You were supposed to shut down Project Protean, not join it!
That's not acceptable!
You got what you wanted: you're out of retirement, with your own organization. How long have you been planning this?
Your goal all along, no doubt.
Would you believe me if I said some of this was happy coincidence?
Protean serves a function, bringing the benefits of alien biology to all people. I can remain at your side while adjusting its approach.
Starting with its work on Joiners.
Your Protean files have already been deleted, and the Killik experiments stopped.
I'm glad everything was resolved satisfactorily. Anything else?
Situation under control, then.
I believe I've told you everything. If you'll excuse me, I have a great deal of research to catch up on.
That's not enough. No more treating people as test subjects--you'll reform Protean, and I'll be watching.
Make sure Protean does good.
I have no desire to make you into an enemy.
He offered to try and cure us. We refused, of course.
We don't entirely understand him. But we don't blame him for Protean's work, or for our Joining--whatever his part really was.
You think he was more involved than he admits?
Do you believe him?
You forgive him that easily. He means something to you.
So you two really are friends.
We don't think he likes people. We don't know why he tolerates us, but... he does, and we're grateful.
We don't always have to trust our friends.
Doctor Lokin is a monster, no matter how he smiles.
He's a dangerous liar.
Maybe. But we're glad to have him with us.
Don't forget you work for me. That means Protean solves my problems now.
I expect results from you.
It will be their pleasure.
We think we're never going to trust him, and we think it doesn't matter.
We're glad he's on our team.
Agent. I've been continuing my research into Project Protean--the fine people who want me dead, and who are responsible for Vector's condition.
I have the location of their headquarters.
Give me the details, doctor.
Let's hear it.
That's quite a breakthrough. How did you get that information?
Where'd you find that out?
By exchanging favors, then spending eighty-two hours deciphering data cube manufacturing codes.
No inquiries into my health? No playful anecdotes as we circle around the topic?
You're not usually so direct.
Not today, I'm afraid.
Protean's main laboratory is on a planetoid in the Subterrel sector. Security is tight, but not impervious.
I've arranged transportation for Vector and myself; he deserves to know the truth about his victimizers.
Once you arrive at the laboratory... what's your goal?
What do you plan to do?
If you're moving against Protean, I ought to be there. Besides, you'll need assistance.
I want to come with you.
I'm afraid this is a personal matter--and I am capable of operating on my own.
You understand we have more on our slate than assaulting Imperial black projects?
This isn't our top priority.
Indeed we do, yet somehow we find time for the "little things."
I plan to learn exactly why Protean tried to kill me and recover their data on Master Vector. The rest we can play by ear.
Take whatever equipment you need, and call me if you run into trouble.
You've got my full support.
I want that man back in one piece. Understood?
Take care of Vector.
Of course.
You've stayed close to him since you came on board. What does Vector mean to you?
Why so focused on him?
He's a curiosity, I admit, but he also has a frustrating honesty about him. I admire that.
We'll see you again when this is over.
Agent, you can bear witness. Doctor Lokin has agreed to hike Kaas Falls with us, if we visit the Kaas City opera.
Vector's musical tastes are, frankly, unsophisticated; I'm only trying to help.
Then we have a deal?
That can wait. Right now, there's something the three of us must discuss.
I think you've got our attention.
Go ahead, doctor.
Would you care to tell me what's going on?
Vector? What's this about?
We're in the dark as well.
Unless you two are plotting a mutiny, I suspect this isn't worth my time.
This must be a joke.
You will want to hear this.
As you are both aware, I've been investigating Project Protean--an off-the-books division of the Imperial Science Bureau.
The people who want you dead.
Precisely. Their research is focused on human-alien genetic splicing. I've studied their files, along with your own physiology, Master Vector, and I've come to a conclusion.
Project Protean arranged your meeting with the Killiks so they could study the Joining.
Why would they do that? And why Vector?
You'd better explain.
Thanks to the Killiks, he's stronger, more capable--an ideal soldier or infiltrator.
A science experiment.
Vector was working for the Diplomatic Service, not the Science Bureau.
How could they arrange that?
Protean is well funded, perfectly able to trade favors with Vector's old superiors.
That part doesn't surprise us.
For what it's worth, I don't believe it was personal. They wanted a test subject, and you were on Alderaan already.
I've tolerated your scheming, but I won't let you manipulate my crew.
If you're lying, doctor...
No manipulations. I can show you the project briefs, the bribes paid to the Diplomatic Service.
We'd like to see them. We believe you, but...
Of course.
Protean hoped Killik alterations could make a better soldier or infiltrator. Vector was a convenient test subject, already stationed on Alderaan.
If this is real, what does it mean for Vector and the rest of us?
What are the implications?
What do you think of all this?
Are you okay, Vector?
We think we are who we are. But we prefer not to be someone else's puppet.
Understandable.
They'll have files on the Killiks. Ways to hurt Joiners, or to heal them. They may have altered Vector, or simply observed him.
I consider it our obligation to find Project Protean and end them, for Vector's sake as well as mine.
Anything else you want to add to this disaster?
This can't get much worse.
They'll have files on the Killiks, of course. Ways to hurt Joiners, ways to heal them. I am fully committed to ending Protean, for Vector's sake as well as mine.
You've pulled a lot of data on these people. Finish the job.
Just get their location.
It will be my pleasure.
If there are answers, we'll find them there.
I guess there's no choice.
Indeed.
If you'll excuse us, we'd like to commune with the hive.
You won't want my advice, but I'll give it anyway. Vector knows who he is. Give him time to be sure of it.
Is it a coincidence that you and Vector, both connected to Project Protean, ended up on my ship?
This is all very suspicious.
Coincidences are not as rare as you might expect. And we have better things to do than piece together history.
He may be right. Our answers are with Protean, in any case.
Now--I will locate our enemy. When I do, you'll know.
A moment.
Hour thirty-six: Subject exhibiting a low-grade fever and elevated N-cell counts. I will proceed to the second formula.
Apologies for that, agent. Bio-experiment logs wait for no man.
Going to say what your experiment is about?
What are you doing?
There's not a lot you can do to surprise me.
I'm used to your oddness.
You're not about to create a new plague, are you?
I don't like how that sounds.
Not if my predictions hold true.
I told you about Project Protean and their research into alien genetics. I managed to gain access to one of their databanks.
Nothing incriminating there, but I was impressed by their scientific data. I've been adapting it for my own studies into the rakghoul virus.
If you're running tests on yourself, you must be confident in the results.
I take it it's going well.
Sample assays can only tell one so much. I'm now in my second day incubating the modified virus.
You made them out to be monsters. Now you're using their research for personal gain?
I'm not sure that's ethical.
The research is done; no point getting squeamish about where it came from.
Do I want to know how you acquired Protean files?
You can access their data?
They make the mistake of sharing supercomputing resources with other Science Bureau divisions. From there it gets technical.
In any case, I'm undergoing my second day incubating the newly modified virus.
If it doesn't break down my cell structure entirely, I should emerge... revivified.
You become a stronger, faster man-eater?
You mean more powerful.
More important, the change itself will be less taxing. It's not unpleasant as-is, but it leaves me with a tremendous headache.
Now if you'll excuse me, this fever is becoming distressing.
You mention the virus now and then, but you never talk about being a rakghoul. Why is that?
Doesn't the change bother you?
Perhaps it's the fever talking, but in truth...
The experience is intense and personal. There's a loss of control, and I wonder if I am man or beast.
If you're on my team, I need to understand. What is it like?
I deserve to know.
I'm sorry. I never realized what you went through.
That must be difficult.
You take me too seriously, agent.
You're playing with me.
I don't believe you.
Only because you can keep up.
If you're worried, however, I reassure you that the thing you see me change into, the thing that eats people?
That thing is me. I have never been a pleasant person.
When you run experiments, I want to know first.
Next time, get my permission.
You're right, of course--it's your ship, and you deserve to know the dangers.
We can resume this discussion when my tongue stops swelling--but in the end, I think you'll see the benefits.
My good friend. Have you noticed that the price of dianogan tea has risen considerably since we broke the Treaty of Coruscant?
One of the costs of war you never anticipate--and now my jamming device is working, so we can dispense with the inanities.
You're not usually this cautious. What's going on?
This must be big news.
What jamming device? What are you talking about?
Jamming device?
Just in case someone's monitoring us.
Don't tell me you've only been chatty to fool eavesdroppers.
I thought you liked babbling.
I enjoy sparkling conversation as much as the next man, but today we have business.
Thanks to a now-wealthy Kubaz information broker, I've identified the people who want me dead.
They represent an organization called "Project Protean"--a secret research and development group inside the Imperial Science Bureau.
What does Protean do, and what do they want?
Who are they?
You are good at this game. Give me the details.
All right, I'm impressed.
We call the Citadel and demand an investigation. Problem solved.
So let's get them shut down.
Black projects aren't so easy to root out, and strictly speaking, I don't have any proof.
Protean researches practical applications of alien biology. You recall the genetically modified assassins who came after me? They're only the beginning.
Imagine troops spliced with Abyssin genes to enhance healing, or adrenals derived from Gamorrean hormones. Most test subjects don't fare well, but you can see the potential.
If they're doing research for the military, why bother with an ex-Fixer?
Then why are they after you?
That sounds awfully like what you were doing on Taris.
Similar to your rakghoul work.
They experiment on people to "enhance" them with alien traits?
That's sickening.
Precisely.
There's a great deal of inter-departmental rivalry in our work, and my research does overlap with theirs.
They may have targeted me in order to ensure that they have no competition--inside or outside the Empire.
Tell me where to find these people. I'm going to talk to them.
I want to meet with them.
This is your operation. What's our next step?
How do you want to proceed?
Further study, I'm afraid.
Why do I think there's more to it than that?
That's not much of a reason.
It's speculative, I'll grant you.
Right now, I'm unsure where the project is based or how to contact its members. But I wanted to keep you apprised.
Now, about that dianogan tea...
What can I do for you, doctor?
Forgive me, but as your sole medical officer, I have to point out that your eating habits have been less than satisfactory lately.
Now, I'll take my share of the blame--I've been preoccupied making calls, catching up on what I've missed in the intelligence community.
Still, the fact that people are trying to kill me does not excuse my neglect of your health.
Any leads on the people who came after you on Balmorra?
Have you learned much, yet?
I appreciate your concern, but you've done a fine job.
Apology accepted.
Says the child to the unstrict parent. But regarding my search, I do have some small amount of news.
Tell me, do you take joy in being obnoxious?
Do you do this to annoy me?
I haven't any idea what you mean. Now, regarding my search, I do have some small amount of news.
I've identified one of the assassins as an operative for Colonel Langor, a man with ties to the Imperial Science Bureau.
The bureau is also the likely origin of the other dead men, whose genetic structure had been mutated--weaponized humans.
What do you mean "weaponized humans"? What's the Science Bureau doing?
The assassins were mutated?
Military research is the bureau's purpose; making humans stronger, faster is one approach.
I've heard of the bureau, but I don't know much about it.
Talk about the Science Bureau.
Military research, organized like an insect's hive of divisions and subdivisions with their own would-be queens.
Which reminds me--I'd like your permission to run some tests on Master Vector.
All that information, from your assassins' charred remains?
You figured out an awful lot.
I am good at my work.
On an unrelated matter, I'd like your permission to run some bioscans on Master Vector.
I'm rather curious about a Joiner's physiology, and Vector is keen to learn more about himself.
If he's willing, go ahead.
No hidden agenda? Just scientific interest?
You're just curious?
And a desire to help a bright young man come to terms with his new self. Believe it or not, I rather like Vector.
If it won't cause harm, I don't have any objections.
All right, then.
Wonderful. I'll let him know the good news--and of course, I'll keep you apprised.
I have questions about him myself. Find out anything you can.
Dissect Vector if you have to.
Certainly. I'll let him know the good news. And of course, I'll keep you apprised.
Stay away from him.
You're not touching any of my crew. Understood?
Don't even think about it.
You make yourself quite clear.
I'll let you know if I hear anything about the Science Bureau.
You made it back. Find anything on Balmorra?
My safe house did, indeed, burn to the ground, along with three would-be assassins who were attempting to wire it with explosives.
Apparently, my security triggered their bombs prematurely.
Do you booby trap all your safe houses? Or just the ones your enemies know about?
That's awfully good security.
You make it sound like I use safe houses as bait.
I assume you're trying to ID these people.
Any idea who they were?
If you'd kept those people alive, we could've questioned them. Now we're out of luck.
You made a careless mistake.
I did acquire genetic samples of the intruders--I'll be running traces shortly. One was a human male, the others... uncertain.
Regardless, they used Imperial equipment and codes to get inside. Someone in the Empire wants me dead.
Supposing you're right... what do you intend to do about it?
Give me your analysis.
This could be a frame job. It wouldn't be hard to arrange.
You're sure they're Imperial?
A wise assertion, although the particulars suggest otherwise.
One way or the other, I take comfort in the fact that I'm once again viewed as a threat. My days in retirement are over.
You wouldn't come to me with no idea of what's going on.
Don't hide anything from me!
The list of people with grudges against me is a long and varied one; it will be some time before I narrow it down.
But I take comfort in the fact that I'm once again viewed as a threat. My days in retirement are over.
Doctor. You wanted to talk?
Yes, and I'm terribly sorry to take your time... but I have a small request.
To be frank, it's a bit of an embarrassment.
You have my undivided attention.
Please, go ahead.
If you need to start feeding on humanoid blood, I don't think I can arrange it.
Having rakghoul problems?
You almost sound like you disapprove. It's nothing of the sort.
Get to the point, or play your games with someone else.
I'm not in a patient mood.
I told you before about my safe houses--how my intruder alarms have been going off? I attributed it to local happenstance.
I may have been mistaken. My safe house on Balmorra exploded.
Would you like to elaborate on that?
"Exploded"?
Very much, but my scanners melted point-seven milliseconds after activation.
Any idea who among your enemies is responsible?
Someone wants you dead.
If only you'd witnessed it in person.
Too bad you weren't there.
As much as I enjoy your jibes, this may not be the appropriate circumstance.
I could theorize regarding who did this and why, but truthfully, all I know is someone bypassed Imperial security to get inside.
I'll need to see the safe house in person; I'll return as soon as I can.
You could be walking into a trap. Stay alert, Doctor.
Be careful out there.
And you.
This isn't the time to play coy. Who do you think did this?
If you know something...
Shall I enumerate everyone who holds a grudge? I'm not being evasive, it is a very long list.
If this is an escape plan, I suggest you think again.
Don't try to abandon us.
If this were an escape plan, I'd have a far more elaborate excuse.
Now, if you'll excuse me, my safehouse awaits.
Well, I'm afraid the news is mixed.
Cipher, I had the most delightful conversation with Master Vector. Did you--I'm getting a feed on my earpiece; one moment.
I apologize. That's the third time this week one of my security alarms has gone off
Where did you set up an alarm system?
Your security alarms?
I take it these alarms don't particularly worry you.
But you don't look troubled.
If there's trouble, let's go. You can brief me on the way.
Guns out, then.
No need for that.
I monitor all my safe houses as a matter of course. I have a few dozen around the galaxy--a precaution, really, I haven't needed them in years.
Usually when an alarm goes off, it means a child has come exploring or a rat has slipped through the ventilation shafts.
You've got havens set up? What's in them?
Tell me about the safe houses.
You know the sort--an abandoned building here, a fortified wine cellar there, stocked with necessities of the trade.
Most of them aren't on the official books, but I assure you, they're hardly incriminating.
One of these days, you're going to say something I actually believe.
That doesn't comfort me.
You're not going to double-check?
Don't you want to make sure?
Hardly worth the bother. I really should dismantle the safe houses altogether, but old habits die hard.
Besides, I hold out hope that I'll need to go to ground someday in one last, exciting adventure.
Remind me not to underestimate you, doctor. If we ever need a sanctuary...
You're a very resourceful man.
You'll have whatever humble aid I can provide.
I don't want to be caught unprepared. Keep an eye on those places.
Let me know about any changes.
I am your humble servant. I'll let you know what I find.
You have an odd sense of humor, doctor.
I assume you're joking.
I haven't a clue what you mean. Shall we move on?
In the future, I won't need trivialities brought to my attention.
Then don't bother me with it.
I entirely understand. I've taken enough of your time already.
My good friend. Allow an old man some sentiment, and join me for a reminiscence.
Today is the thirtieth anniversary of the death of Cipher Twelve--one of the finest agents I've ever worked with.
I've never heard of a Cipher Twelve--they don't mention our predecessors much.
Tell me about him.
Our history is fleeting, to say the least.
You have my sympathies, doctor.
I'm sorry to hear that.
No need for that--it has been thirty years, but I like to pay my respects.
You commemorate a dead man after thirty years?
You're not usually emotional.
An obligation of the trade. If we don't remember one another, there's no one else who will.
Cipher Twelve was one of the old guard, from before the war. He cultivated allies on the fringes.
By the time he received his Mandalorian brands, he'd also become verbally abusive in private--but he never cracked on the job. Always had a smile.
If he was so capable, what happened to him?
Until he died, you mean.
Were you partners?
What did you two do together?
I was technical advisor on several of his assignments, and we shared a taste in Mirialan cuisine.
Men who can handle the stress don't become "verbally abusive."
He doesn't sound admirable.
Granted--some drink or womanize, and some ritualize their behaviors. I've seen every coping mechanism imaginable.
Eventually the odds caught up with him, and a Hapani royal assassin punctured his lungs.
Inevitable, really. Are you aware of how few Ciphers survive past year five?
The odds aren't good for any of us.
I've heard it mentioned.
Quite so.
Of all the things that go wrong in this job, dying isn't so bad. Failure, though...
Death isn't what worries me.
Rather my point.
Not many Ciphers survive fighting Jedi and Sith, either.
I'm good at beating the odds.
More than you might suppose.
I admire the line you walk between obedience and ingenuity. Unfortunately, your methods breed enemies.
Be careful not to end up without recourse.
There's some truth there, I'll admit. We'll see what happens.
I'll give it some thought.
Friendly advice from one who knows.
You chose to join my crew. If you didn't like my methods, you could've found a way out by now. What are you after?
Why so interested in me?
I've heard it before. It's no more convincing coming from you.
I'm doing fine without advice.
I've made it through a very long career by choosing my partners wisely. I've outlasted them all--and I intend to keep doing so.
Cipher, join us! Vector and I were just discussing Moff Lett-Shara.
We never met her, of course...
Quite fortunate, that. But Vector did know her husband, a fine dejarik player and scribe of the Ilthmar Gambit.
We apparently share the doctor's taste in theater.
By all means, continue.
Don't stop on my account.
I wouldn't want to take your time, but Master Vector, we should talk again.
Of course, doctor.
I didn't know you were interested in theater.
Is that a hobby of yours?
Think of it as a testing ground for human nature. Much like the game of dejarik.
We can finish this later, doctor.
You're not here to chit-chat. Make yourselves useful.
Get back to work, both of you.
We should tend to our fingerlings.
The distraction was my fault.
Your crew members are delightful people--for instance, did you know Mistress Kaliyo is fluent in Kaleesh profanities? A rare and admirable skill.
I wonder how you manage them. Leadership is such a delicate thing.
My team knows what they're doing.
I trust them and their skills.
A fine philosophy until one stabs you in the back. Still, it's good you value their comradery.
You sound like you've thought about this.
I'd be happy to take advice.
I confess, it has crossed my mind.
Leadership is making sure people know their place.
They follow my orders.
Spoken like a true Imperial patriot. Still, you should value their comradery.
A dead or alienated colleague is a resource lost, and in our business, it's a small step from being disliked to being blacklisted.
Alienate enough people, and you find yourself running unauthorized missions on a dead planet?
Is that what happened to you?
Quite. I could tell you stories.
I appreciate the benefit of your experience.
I'll keep that in mind.
And I appreciate your company.
But I'm afraid I have to attend to my data analysis program. Another time, Cipher.
I'll say this once--don't interfere with my people.
Stay away from my crew.
You make it sound like you mistrust me. I'll do nothing to jeopardize you or your mission.
Perhaps we should talk on the ship? When you have the time, of course.
I'd like a word with you when you get a moment.
I am at your service, agent.
Indeed.
As you wish.
Of course, agent.
Of course. I'll watch your back.
I'll be with you in just a moment.
If you insist.
I have the utmost confidence in you.
Of course, of course.
I'll do my very best.
All in due time.
You are beginning to impress me.
I see I'll have to leave you your space.
Cipher, I'm a technician. What would I possibly do?
